messageBody:
Robert Wenner wrote:

> On Wednesday 14 July 2004 22:05, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > I always throw Exception from tests, because I /know/ (one of the rare
> > times I know something) that I want to let JUnit catch any unexpected
> > exceptions.
>
> I don't like that throws Exception, even not for Tests.
> I can not exactly say why, but it is something along these lines: The
> tests drive development. They are the first users of the production code
> and if they are hard to write, other production code that uses the code
> under test will also be hard to write. Development includes thrown
> exception types (throw specifications). If I write throws Exception at
> each unit test, I may hide a cumbersome exception specification in the
> code under test -- in production code I don't want to have throws
> Exception attached to every method.

You're right: I might hide a cumbersome exception specification, but
something else I do seems to compensate for that, because I can't
remember the last time it bit me.

I am confused, though: why does "throws Exception" in a test lead to
"throws Exception" in production code? That doesn't happen to me. What
typically happens is:

1. I write the test for code that will use code that throws a checked
exception. I don't notice.

2. I write the production code, at which point I realize that I need to
catch a checked exception, so in my production code, I have this:

....
catch (CheckedException wrapped) {
throw new RuntimeException("Something went wrong doing X", wrapped);
}

3. I look up the situation under which the code I'm /using/ (not
writing) throws CheckedException.

4. I write down exception handling tests on my test list.

I can follow this relatively simple ritual and avoid missing checked
exception specifications.

> In short terms: I write no throws to my tests, unless the compiler
> complain, and the more often I have to do that, the more often I think
> about my throw specifications.

Different strokes for different folks. I used to do this, and it seemed
only to cost me without benefiting me. Maybe I need to try again.
